newsitem.title: USA: Peru would use new bonds to buy back Bradies-Camet.
newsitem.headline: Peru would use new bonds to buy back Bradies-Camet.

text.p: Peru's finance minister Jorge Camet said on Wednesday that Peru would use fresh bond issues and not rely on its fiscal surplus if it opted to repurchase existing foreign debt.
He told Reuters financial television that Peru had studied the possibility of repurchasing its Brady bonds, but had not yet come to a decision.
He also said that Peru did not know how intense the "El Nio" weather effect would be this year, but the government was making contingency plans to reduce potential flooding in agricultural areas.
He noted that El Nio would not have a major effect on Peru's economy.
"With a major Nio effect, growth could be five percent, if not, it could be six to seven percent," Camet said.
Camet said that Peru would likely see a credit rating upgrade later this year.
"Our rating should be better than what it is now," Camet said.
Peru is currently rated B2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc but is not rated by Standard & Poor's Corp.
